dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, the recent Biden-Xi summit in San Francisco, right? Lots of talk about it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, the recent Biden-Xi summit in San Francisco, right? Lots of talk about it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for sure. You know, you hear about them stopping military communication, which sounds pretty dicey. But then, like, China dramatically increasing fentanyl chemical exports, and the US *lauding* that? That's… confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for sure. You know, you hear about them stopping military communication, which sounds pretty dicey. But then, like, China dramatically increasing fentanyl chemical exports, and the U S lauding that? That's confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, the two countries will resume military-to-military communication, thereby reducing the chances of an accidental conflict, and China will do more to restrict the export of chemicals used to make the powerful synthetic opioid fentanyl a major cause of death in the United States.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. But here’s the wild part of this article: apparently, the *real* area of rapid progress, believe it or not, was tariffs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. But here's the wild part of this article: apparently, the real area of rapid progress, believe it or not, was tariffs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But there is one crucial area where progress remained elusive: tariffs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, interesting! I mean, I always think of tariffs as this big, contentious thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, interesting! I mean, I always think of tariffs as this big, contentious thing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But the article says back in 2018, Trump's admin actually lowered tariffs on Chinese imports, like, from over 3% to 2%. And China responded in kind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But the article says back in twenty eighteen, Trump's admin actually lowered tariffs on Chinese imports, like, from over three percent to two percent. And China responded in kind.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, then-US President Donald Trumps administration hiked the tariff rate on imports from China from slightly over 3% to more than 21% a level unseen in the US since before World War II.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, I didn't realize that. And the summit was, uh, apparently a "disaster" because they argued about *maintaining* these tariffs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, I didn't realize that. And the summit was, uh, apparently a disaster because they argued about maintaining these tariffs?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And yet, despite the benefits that reducing tariffs would bring, the US Trade Representative did not attend the San Francisco summit, suggesting that Biden never intended to discuss the issue at all.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! Which is, like, counter-intuitive because a lot of people think tariffs are inherently bad.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! Which is, like, counter-intuitive because a lot of people think tariffs are inherently bad.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But the WTO actually ruled that Trump's tariffs were totally compatible with international rules.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the W T O actually ruled that Trump's tariffs were totally compatible with international rules.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In any case, a WTO panel ruled in 2020 that the Trump tariffs are incompatible with Americas legal obligation to abide by the organizations rules.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And this article makes a pretty strong case that keeping these tariffs actually strengthens the international trading system and, surprisingly, helps households in both countries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And this article makes a pretty strong case that keeping these tariffs actually strengthens the international trading system and, surprisingly, helps households in both countries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US insistence on maintaining the tariffs not only undermines the rules-based international trading system, but also hurts households and firms in both countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: How so? Because, you know, we always hear tariffs mean higher prices for consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: How so? Because, you know, we always hear tariffs mean higher prices for consumers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's the opposite if you *remove* them, apparently. If we got rid of the Trump tariffs, the cost of living for Americans would go up by, like, one percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's the opposite if you remove them, apparently. If we got rid of the Trump tariffs, the cost of living for Americans would go up by, like, one percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taken together, these effects would permanently reduce the cost of living to Americans by about one percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, really? Because of input costs and everything?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? Because of input costs and everything?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because 40% of what we import from China is parts and components. So, removing tariffs means those parts get more expensive, and then *our* finished goods get pricier too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because forty percent of what we import from China is parts and components. So, removing tariffs means those parts get more expensive, and then our finished goods get pricier too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 40% of US imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods, so removing the Trump tariffs would also lower input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, the US economy takes a hit, jobs, incomes…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, the U S economy takes a hit, jobs, incomes...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This would benefit the competitiveness of US goods in the Chinese market, thereby bolstering jobs and incomes not only for US exporters, but also for their input suppliers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. And China probably wouldn't remove *their* tariffs on our goods if we removed ours, making our exports less competitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. And China probably wouldn't remove their tariffs on our goods if we removed ours, making our exports less competitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given that China has always characterized its tariff increases on US goods as retaliatory, one can assume that it would remove them if the Trump tariffs were reversed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, Biden… he should actually *want* to keep these tariffs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Biden... he should actually want to keep these tariffs?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But he should communicate to voters that removing the Trump tariffs would be good for American households and firms. Not doing so is a failure of leadership.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's what the article argues! It suggests he could use it as a smart political move, you know? Tell voters keeping them is good for their wallets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's what the article argues! It suggests he could use it as a smart political move, you know? Tell voters keeping them is good for their wallets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But he should communicate to voters that removing the Trump tariffs would be good for American households and firms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] So, appearing "soft on China" by discussing tariffs, then saying he's keeping them because it helps Americans. That's pretty clever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, appearing soft on China by discussing tariffs, then saying he's keeping them because it helps Americans. That's pretty clever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is said that Biden does not want to give the Republicans a reason to say that he is soft on China. But he should communicate to voters that removing the Trump tariffs would be good for American households and firms.
